Key Arguments: The problem the legislation aims to solve is not clearly defined, and existing laws may already address the issues.
The bill lacks clarity on why it targets harm to groups rather than individuals and how such harm would be measured.
The bill does not balance free speech with the suppression of misinformation and disinformation, potentially leading to over-censorship.
The bill should be integrated into the Competition and Consumer Act 2010 and overseen by the ACCC, which is better suited for this role.
Definitions of misinformation and disinformation should be provided by the Minister through regulation, not inferred by ACMA or ACCC.
Main Themes: Lack of clarity and justification for the legislation
Notable Quotes: The proponents have not identified a public policy problem necessitating Australian Government intervention.
It is not clear why legislation is needed to address harm to groups of people rather than individuals.
The uncertainty will defeat the aim of the Bill i.e. it will not prevent misinformation/disinformation being amplified within the community without impinging on free speech.
To avoid confusion, any statement which is considered to be false, misleading or deceptive should be defined by the Minister through a regulation.
